Pro: Unfortunately, there is a built in positive feedback loop when CO2 accumulates in the atmosphere. The oceans are the main component of the natural CO2 cycle, and as the water warms, it begins to release more than it absorbs. Thus CO2 makes it warmer, which in turn releases more CO2, which makes it warmer, etc. We could reach a tipping point where the whole thing starts to run away, and time may be shorter than we realize.
Pro: It seems a perfect fit for the old adage, better safe than sorry.

Con: The rule for high stakes games is to avoid drastic measures unless absolutely necessary. To take slow and careful action and seek consensus. If we overshoot an attempt to alter our climate, it could be worse than the current dilemna

childs.tile: Con: Increased 'radiative forcing' from higher CO2 levels is settled science, but the additional 'feedbacks' (mostly from H2O) are not settled science. These feedbacks account for the majority of projected warming.

childs.title: Con: There is uncertainty about the contribution of aerosols to radiative forcing, but projected warming is less uncertain. As of 2011, the combined (positive and negative) radiative forcing due to human activity was assessed at 2.3 W/m^2 (Sec 1.2.1, p44), supported by observation. This number has better certainty than the details of aerosol contribution. If we continue business-as-usual, the credible uncertainty about passing 1.5C is about whether it will happen in ~1-2 decades or ~4 decades.

Con: Uncertainties in radiative forcing are offset by the estimation of the 'sensitivity coefficient'. The two of them combine to form the Transient Climate Response, which is constrained by observation, and has less uncertainty. (Avg 0.1C to 0.3C per decade, currently ~0.2C/decade).

childs.tile: Con: Several features of drastic climate changes, specifically negative and positive feedback loops, have not been observed under the predicted higher temperatures. And may well be able to offset the greenhouse gas effect. climate.nasa.gov
